comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: David Franklin Houston (1866-1940) was Chancellor of Washington University in St. Louis (1908-1913), and US Secretary of Agriculture (1913-1920), then briefly was the US Secretary of the Treasury after that: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_F._Houston

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: The unidentified man at the left. looking like an undertaker, is William Gibbs McAdoo, Secretary of the Treasury in the administration of President Woodrow Wilson. Secretaries McAdoo and Houston formed a two-man committee charged with selecting cities in which to locate Federal Reserve Banks, under terms of the new Federal Reserve Act. Their first hearings were held in New York City (here, at the N. Y. Customs House) and in Boston. The New York hearings opened on Monday, January 5, 1914. Story in the New York Times, January 7, 1914 (other related stories preceded it): query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9901E... William Gibbs McAdoo, on Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Gibbs_McAdoo

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content:
A related Bain/LOC photo, also from January, 1914, shows the extravagantly-proportioned Milton C. Elliott, an attorney who served as counsel to the Federal Reserve Board, and obviously carried a lot of weight in American banking circles:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4732557037/in/photostream/]

comment._content: Thanks for identifying McAdoo. We'll add his name when we update.

comment.author: 60934085@N02
comment._content: The above comments on Wm. McAdoo and D. F. Houston I believe to be correct. D.F Houston was my grandfather.
